articles.headline: If Your Wi-Fi Is Terrible, Check Your Router
articles.snippet: Many frustrating speed bottlenecks at home can be traced to that dusty old box in your basement.
articles.abstract: Many frustrating speed bottlenecks at home can be traced to that dusty old box in your basement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bob McConnell, a retired engineer, set up a new wireless router in his home this year to get faster Internet speeds. Instead, he got the opposite, with his iPad often getting no wireless connection in his bedroom.

articles.headline: Jury Clears Former Dewey Leaders of Some Charges, but Is Deadlocked on Others
articles.snippet: The judge said he would direct the jurors to return to deliberations, asking them to try to reach a verdict on the outstanding charges.
articles.abstract: The judge said he would direct the jurors to return to deliberations, asking them to try to reach a verdict on the outstanding charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: A criminal trial of three former leaders of Dewey & LeBoeuf, already more than four months long, is edging closer to the finishing line.

articles.headline: Obama Issues Rare Apology Over Bombing of Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Five days after the U.S. bombed an Afghan hospital, the president’s personal apology appeared to do little to satisfy the leader of the doctors group.
articles.abstract: Five days after the U.S. bombed an Afghan hospital, the president’s personal apology appeared to do little to satisfy the leader of the doctors group.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama personally apologized on Wednesday to the head of Doctors Without Borders for what he described as the mistaken bombing of its field hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, promising a full investigation into the episode, which took the lives of nearly two dozen doctors and patients.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Opposes Obama’s Trans-Pacific Trade Deal
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton said that she does not support the 12-nation trade pact, while liberals in the Democratic Party have vehemently opposed it.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton said that she does not support the 12-nation trade pact, while liberals in the Democratic Party have vehemently opposed it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton dealt a significant blow to President Obama in his efforts to secure approval from Congress on his signature trade agreement, saying on Wednesday she could not support the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the 12-nation trade pact that she bolstered as secretary of state and that liberals in the Democratic Party have vehemently opposed.

articles.headline: I.M.F. Gathers Experts to Evaluate Global Preparedness for Fiscal Crisis
articles.snippet: Driving these global worries is the fear that the dollar-based debt in large emerging market economies has risen to unsustainable levels.
articles.abstract: Driving these global worries is the fear that the dollar-based debt in large emerging market economies has risen to unsustainable levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — As financial leaders gather here this week to assess the health of the world economy, one of the central topics for discussion will be how ready markets are for a crisis in a large developing economy such as China, Turkey or Brazil.

articles.headline: NATO, Tested by Russia in Syria, Raises Its Guard and Its Tone
articles.snippet: Western military officials said they were deploying some logistics personnel in Central and Eastern Europe, raising tensions with Moscow.
articles.abstract: Western military officials said they were deploying some logistics personnel in Central and Eastern Europe, raising tensions with Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Confronted with its biggest military challenge since the end of the Cold War, a weakened NATO took steps Thursday to shore up its flanks, both in the Middle East and Europe, as Russia continued to test the credibility of the alliance’s bedrock principle of collective defense.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and James Kanter

articles.headline: Delays as Death-Penalty States Scramble for Execution Drugs
articles.snippet: Despite a Supreme Court ruling allowing a controversial drug to be used for lethal injections, states are not finding it easier to execute inmates.
articles.abstract: Despite a Supreme Court ruling allowing a controversial drug to be used for lethal injections, states are not finding it easier to execute inmates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite a Supreme Court ruling allowing a controversial drug to be used for lethal injections in Oklahoma, death-penalty states are finding it harder to carry out executions as they struggle to obtain and properly use limited supplies of ever-changing combinations of suitable drugs.

articles.headline: Seattle, in Midst of Tech Boom, Tries to Keep Its Soul
articles.snippet: The city’s leaders are hoping to avoid the pitfalls bedeviling San Francisco — surging home prices, less diversity — as its tech scene expands.
articles.abstract: The city’s leaders are hoping to avoid the pitfalls bedeviling San Francisco — surging home prices, less diversity — as its tech scene expands.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For years, business leaders here have closely studied the San Francisco region, seeking to emulate the way it churns out so many leading technology companies.

articles.headline: Regulators Investigating 2nd VW Computer Program on Emissions
articles.snippet: Volkswagen and regulators declined to say whether the software in diesel cars, newly disclosed during congressional testimony, was intended to defeat emissions control tests.
articles.abstract: Volkswagen and regulators declined to say whether the software in diesel cars, newly disclosed during congressional testimony, was intended to defeat emissions control tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal and California regulators have begun an investigation into a second computer program in Volkswagen’s diesel cars that also affects the operation of the cars’ emission controls.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Penny Pritzker Tackles Tough Assignments as Commerce Secretary
articles.snippet: From meetings in Cuba to promoting a 12-nation Pacific trade deal, Ms. Pritzker is known for her work ethic, and her long association with President Obama.
articles.abstract: From meetings in Cuba to promoting a 12-nation Pacific trade deal, Ms. Pritzker is known for her work ethic, and her long association with President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Penny Pritzker, the commerce secretary and billionaire entrepreneur who travels the world in her private Gulfstream jet, was here this week to try to meld Cuban socialism with American capitalism. It was not always a comfortable fit.
